GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Crusaders Base
Allmother's Shrine
Generates 1000 Aura Coins each turn.
Allmother's Temple
Generates 500 additional Aura Coins.
Allmother's Catedral
Generates 1000 additional Aura Coins.
Allmother's Crown
Generates<color=SOTS_COLOR_GOLD> 1000</color> additional <color=SOTS_COLOR_GOLD>Aura coins</color> per turn and further increases unit production.
Replicator
Generates 1 Biomass and 1 Radiant.
Gateway
Allows commanders to instantly travel between bases.
Cellars
Allows you to hire commanders.
Bath House
Adds one more commander for hire. Commanders start with one random piece of equipment.
Altar of Purity
Increases visibility range around the base and senses useful objects in an even larger area.
Recycler
Generates 1 limerite and 1 Alloy
Factory
Allows you to build unit-blocking shields for your armies.
Trading Post
Allows you to exchange of resources and money.
Citadel
Builds walls, a gate, and two shooting platforms and unlocks an additional defensive slot.
Tower
Walls and gate are stronger. Adds 2 additional range platforms and 1 more defensive slot.
Mines
3 mines appear on a siege battlefield.
Turret
Two hidden turrets on a siege battlefield.
Gravitor belt
(Will be implemeted during Early Access development)
Electric Gate and Walls
(Will be implemeted during Early Access development)
Ossuary
Dismantles mechanical units into pieces and makes brand new Custodians instead.
Grand Library
Unlocks three random abilities to learn.
Feathered Antennae
Commander can learn abilitiesy outside of their base.
Great Archive
Unlocks the chance to buy new abilities.
Library of Organics
Unlocks bio abilities to learn.
Library of Geograpy
Unlocks exploration abilities to learn.
Library of Indefinite Studies
Unlocks psy abilities to learn.
Library of Technology
Unlocks tech abilities to learn.
Custodians Tents
Allows you to recruit Custodian Novices.
Cleric Tents
Allows you to recruit Custodian Clerics.
Temple Guardpost
Allows you to recruit Temple Guards.
Temple Barracks
Allows you to recruit Templar Warriors.
Bright Nest
Allows you to recruit The Bright Ones.
Blazing Hive
Allows you to recruit The Blazing Ones.
Tower of Principle
Allows you to recruit Knights.
Tower of Faith
Allows you to recruit Knight Champions.
Windowless Fort
Allows you to recruit Zieregals
Windowless Keep
Allows you to recruit High Zieregals
Spitfire Maze
Allows you to recruit Spitfires.
Spitfire Dungeon
Allows you to recruit Spitfire Zealots.
Portal
Allows you to recruit Acherons.
Ascended Portal
Allows you to recruit Blessed Acherons.
Allmother's statue
Generates 8 additional Temple Guards.
Holy Arches
Void Heart
Tallest Steeple
Cloudy Grace
Altar of the Prism
High Nexus

Drowned out by the velvety shadows of the nave, there is only one islet of light. On it stands a tall, sleek statue of the Goddess. The steel-casted body reflects a solitary beam of light on the small group of worshipers below.

Surprisingly, for most of the ceremony, worshipers stand with their backs to the Allmother statue. It isn't an act of defiance; it's a message. She isn't here for them; they've come to protect HER. Many have come today.
More pilgrims arrive seeking shelter in Allmother's stronghold - Not only robots and cyborgs but organics, too. The cathedral is crowded; the bright light banished the shadows once again.
With the Crown, the cathedral has become a beacon, attracting a sea of worshipers. But still, the giant cathedral seems dwarfed by the distant mirage of the Great Allmother's Temple in Temple City.

The offerings have become largely symbolic, but even now, a body piece is required. A scrap of wire, a few droplets of battery fluid or... Clearly, the church has not fully digested the idea of flesh-and-bone followers.

It's not about recycling. It's about consuming resources produced by others. In this case, long-dead Primals. But still! Clearly, species evolution was counting on more than just a single planet at its disposal.

One of the carefully guarded secrets is the gateway principle. It's either a curvature of space or a disintegration followed by a somewhat jarring reintegration. If you don't believe in the soul, it is not a problem, but if you do, the consequence of the latter option is rather scary.

When the Children of the Source opened their arms to organics, alcohol, traditionally used only for cleaning, found another purpose. Surprisingly, its quality is much higher than the swill served by the Fossorians.

Only mechanical travelers come to wash their bodies. The rest can at least clean their dirty shoes or something. Remember, maintenance is the key to eternal function. Besides, you know... not getting killed.

Altars are cleaning the air around the base, enabling us to see much farther, but the latest discovery may put an end to this endeavor. A UNSS defector claims that the bases can now be easily targeted from orbit.

For centuries, the Children of the Source used their own "aggressive" version of a force shield. Yet when the humans introduced a superior version, it was abandoned with surprising swiftness. Maybe there is hope for the Children after all.

After the last disastrous crusade, the Children of the Source can stand alone no more. Although the order still tries to project strength, their desperation shows through their hasty effort to establish trade roads and defense pacts.

There is a common myth that the Children are simply manufactured. They are not. All new warriors are excavated from ancient battlefields and wrecks. Restarted, repaired, and re-equipped. The fast track to extinction, you say? Well, the council knows.

Learning should be easy because all knights are robots, right? It's not that simple. For every combatant with a personality, there needs to be a mechanism protecting them from emotional overload. And the most effective is a good old forgetting.

During the Holy War, both sides tried to silence the enemy's communication, and both succeeded with flying colors. The majority of ancient jammers are still online. Add to it gargantuan atmospheric distortions, and you'll celebrate every kilobyte that squeaks through.

Precise record-keeping, established over the centuries, crumbled under the weight of new information only weeks after the newcomers appeared in the Siren system. No one knows why. You wouldn't think that robo-librarians could look exhausted, but they do.
There are no navigators more skillful than the Children of the Source. Many knights dedicated centuries to the precise mapping of the planets. As if looking for the Goddess wasn't only metaphorical.

Aside from their educational role, tech monks tackle some big theological questions. Can UNSS smart toasters be judged as heretic? It ended with a fire, but don't be prejudous. Exhausted from hours of lengthy questioning, the toasters' batteries self-ignited.

Tumori tribes. The sworn enemies of the Allmother are techno-barbarians except in one discipline - Biotechnology. Although the majority of the Children are inorganic, their understanding of the enemy helps them survive so long.

Even though the Children of the Source are inorganic, centuries of Primal artifact research allowed them to uncover fundamental tools for influencing the mind. It appears that their minds aren't so different from the organics.

According to legend, Children of the Source pursued the Primals from Allmother's homeworld to the Siren system. It must have been a long "chase" because the Children's ships never had a hyperdrive. For some, age is truly only a number.
Since the Holy War, the Children of the Source have focused solely on assault tactics. Walls and other defenses are just afterthoughts tacked on by the desperate battle outcomes.
Before the last crusade, this option would be swept off the table as dishonorable. But since most paragons of knighthood perished in the last crusade, brave new ideas are approved much much easier.

Today's church presents the Allmother as a kind goddess, but one look at the terrifying insectoid face that adorns the gates, and you realize that she ain't going to be handing out Christmas presents at the mall. Not in a million years.
Sacrificing your mechanical body to help those in need is considered one of the church's most venerated doctrines. Whether you do so voluntarily is beside the point.

One of the Church's countless pledges encourages a life of minimalism. That's why the Custodians stay in simple tents. With their obsession with ornamental decorations, thick walls, and rare materials, the children's architects clearly have trouble with that one.

Though outstanding for physical violence, the giant, heavy frames of other Children of the Source tend to get stuck in service shafts—the natural domain of the Custodians. IT's only shame that no original ship is in flying condition.

Usually silent and still as statues, do not mistake them for honor guards with funny furry hats that only exist for tourists to make faces at. A few guests foolish enough to openly criticize their temple remain missing to this day.
The template temple guard specimens must have been aggressive, "bad neighbor" types. Are they equipped with shields, the universal symbol of protection? Nope. They wield only assault weapons.

The Bright One's took the concept of a living weapon quite literally. They ditched all their limbs so their enemies had nothing to grab, but now they can't even plug themselves in. Probably not the best idea in hindsight.
They communicate with each other in binary via flickering lights. Watching them argue can be pretty dazzling and is not recommended for those with light sensitivity issues or epilepsy.

Despite orders, some knights joined the mercenary groups that operate against the hated Tumori tribes. The church claims they are malfunctioning, but they simply can't stand to hide beyond the walls when there is "work" to do.

You can easily recognize the Knights from the rest of the Children. If you hide behind an armored door, most Children try to cut through it with power blades, lasers, or concentrated flames. Knights simply rip the door off the wall.

Zieregals supervise trials for new converts. Don't think of it as a barbaric box of pain or a fight to the death. It's a simple lore test—nothing to worry about. But if you fail, they WILL "deactivate you" like any other defective unit.

There is a reason the Zieregal keep has no windows, but it's only revealed once you're inside. I don't know about you, but I'll pass thanks. They always find something if they want to dig up some dirt on you.
The Spitfire recipe for "Helly-water," a flaming cocktail, is not the secret of some Southern Colonel. They can use just about any flammable liquid, and their digestive organs take care of the rest.

It was sheer luck that the UNSS expedition didn't come across any Spitfire on day one and even greater luck that brought the Fossorians to a small Spitfire force or the balance would have shifted between the factions.

How can a two-ton cyborg possibly soar like a leaf in the wind? They possess Gravitor technology that would be the envy of a fat man from Giedi Prime. It's only a matter of time till the other factions try to steal it.

There are Holly War records that claim the Acheron legion is trapped in the Primal Vault. The legend says they will come to the Children's aid in a moment of great need. It's only a story, though otherwise, they would have shown up during the last crusade.
Consumable Market
Buy or sell consumables! Replenished at the beginning of each cycle.
The tradition of the clergy providing goods for the wider population has stood the test of time, even though the physical needs of artificial beings are somewhat limited.
